stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on the Bowser construction/oil-rig themed level (“Bowser protest”), focusing on visual readability (coins, switch model, crane colors) and—most of all—solving N64 rendering constraints for an “infinite” ocean/background using fog, horizon gradients, and draw-order/layer fixes. He also does an on-hardware performance check, shares stability/debugging updates (Up64 crash fix, new NEMU64 build), and discusses merchandising/legal-adjacent monetization ideas (selling N64-style boxes and an OST ROM).
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains concrete technical discoveries (F3D vs F3DEX2 export, culling/sorting/collision optimization plan, Up64 crash fix) plus a long, decision-driving exploration of skybox/ocean rendering limits on N64 and a rare extended business/legal monetization brainstorm (selling boxes without ROM, OST ROM, paying contributors).

findings.summary: Kaze feels the Bowser construction/oil-rig level is visually “too dead” and decides to populate it with more coins (coin rings, formations) to improve readability and liveliness.
findings.quote: I feel like this level is missing something… it’s missing a lot of coins that we put everywhere. Like this is too dead for me.

findings.summary: He chooses to keep the classic Mario 64 Bowser-stage floor switch interaction (rather than a lever) because it communicates “Bowser level” language immediately and matches player expectations from the original game.
findings.quote: Every Bowser level in Mario 64 uses this exact switch… this is just a very Mario 64 Bowser design.

findings.summary: Zeina is absent this stream; Kaze notes an animation for a character/NPC in the level would likely have been finished if she were available, indicating an art/animation dependency gating certain level polish.
findings.quote: Unfortunately Zeina's gone today. Otherwise, she maybe would have finished the animation for the guy here.

findings.summary: On real N64 testing, Kaze discovers the level was accidentally exported as an F3D model (not F3DEX2), which doubles certain rendering costs—yet it still held up, implying extra headroom once exported correctly.
findings.quote: I was exporting it as an F3D model and not F3DEX2… twice the vertex loads… and it still ran fine.

findings.summary: He identifies multiple planned performance wins still not implemented: backface culling (especially for gate geometry), triangle sorting, render-area/culling partitioning, and building a collision map to reduce collision triangles.
findings.quote: This is an 8000 polygon level. No render areas… We didn't even sort the triangles yet… we didn't make a collision map yet. Which will also help.

findings.summary: Kaze reports he likely found and fixed the bug that caused only “Up64” to crash, and says RTYI is now very stable on N64—an important stability milestone even if not tied to a public release.
findings.quote: I think I found the bug that caused only Up64 to crash. And now RTYI is so stable on the N64.

findings.summary: He explains how to get true world/directional lighting in Mario 64: the original engine transforms the world around the camera (no standard view matrix), so he uses Wiseguy’s Matrix Stack Fix to prevent lights from being camera-transformed.
findings.quote: You need to use Wiseguy's Matrix Stack Fix… then you just put a light, and it will be a world light.

findings.summary: While adding coin formations, the level exhibits severe visual corruption; Kaze suspects model load/unload state issues (the coin model may be getting unloaded per-area) and/or memory corruption triggered by an object/geo definition, but he doesn’t fully root-cause it during the stream.
findings.quote: I think the yellow coin model got unloaded… The coin model is loaded per area and you need to call special code to load it again… That is actually very concerning.

findings.summary: Kaze highlights the core N64 limitation blocking his “infinite ocean” idea: a hardware culling radius causes far geometry to disappear, making certain skybox/NBG ocean tricks fundamentally break when level elements visually touch the background at playable camera heights.
findings.quote: If anything's too far away from the camera it's gonna just not be visible… it's a hardware limitation… I think the idea is fundamentally wrong.

findings.summary: He iterates toward a workable ocean/background solution by combining fog, a horizon gradient aligned with the water edge, and camera-follow translation tuning; he aims for an illusion of vastness without claustrophobic fog or visible skybox “eating” the level.
findings.quote: We’re slowly figuring out the best skybox here… The horizon line has to look very flat for it to work.

findings.summary: Biobak supplies an improved floor-switch model/texture that Kaze prefers because it reads like a faithful “upgraded” Mario 64 switch while remaining efficient (much lower poly than an alternative).
findings.quote: This is so much better than the one we had before. This actually just looks like an upgraded version of the Mario 64 one.

findings.summary: Kaze notes a newly updated build of NEMU64 (originally from 2002) is now useful again and supports serious debugging workflows (GDB plugin), suggesting a shift in his debugging toolchain.
findings.quote: They updated it… and it's so much better now. And you can debug everything with it.

findings.summary: A merch company contacted Kaze offering custom products; he considers selling N64-style boxes with manuals as merch. He speculates that selling the box without the ROM could be legal, and also proposes selling a separate ROM that contains only the OST.
findings.quote: When I sell RTYI, I could just sell the box without the ROM, and it'd be legal. And then I would also make a ROM that's just the OST and sell that.

findings.summary: Kaze discusses compensation: he agrees in principle to pay collaborators (including musicians) via royalties/rights once revenue exists, implying he’s thinking about formalizing contributor agreements.
findings.quote: I was offering to pay the musicians as well, for like the rights to the music, once everything's done.

findings.summary: Kaze confirms he has a full-time programming job (CFP) alongside the project, limiting available development time and shaping stream/work cadence.
findings.quote: I have been working on this over a few months now, but I have a full-time job on the side.

biobak.summary: Proposes/encourages a blue-ish horizon/gradient approach for the ocean/skybox seam to help the sea read as distant and continuous.
Delivers a revised Bowser-level floor-switch asset that keeps a classic Mario 64 feel while improving visual quality and fitting in a small texture footprint.

zeina.summary: Kaze implies Zeina’s animation work is an active dependency for finishing/polishing at least one character/NPC in the level; she is not present this stream so that piece does not progress.

findings.summary: Suggests visual tweaks (platform shading concerns, horizon color ideas) and pushes for background improvements to make the level feel less empty.

Raises ideas about camera-relative background movement/pitch and Blender render/color settings (view transform), though Kaze concludes the setting was already correct and remains skeptical of some suggestions.
Creator of Matrix Stack Fix, which Kaze relies on to enable proper world lighting in the decomp-based engine.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: If decomp didn't exist, I would just make my own video games I think. Maybe I'd be making a game in assembly right now.
memorable_quotes.context: A revealing statement about how the decomp enabled RTYI, and how strong his drive to build games is even without modern tooling.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: When I sell RTYI, I could just sell the box without the ROM, and it'd be legal. And then I would also make a ROM that's just the OST and sell that.
memorable_quotes.context: Captures his emerging business/legal strategy for monetizing a Nintendo-adjacent project while trying to avoid distributing infringing content.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I think the idea is fundamentally wrong… It’s impossible.
memorable_quotes.context: His turning point while wrestling with N64 background/ocean rendering constraints, deciding certain skybox/NBG approaches cannot work when geometry touches the background.

key_stories.title: The level ran fine despite an accidental worst-case export
key_stories.summary: While performance-testing the Bowser construction level on N64, Kaze realizes he exported the geometry as F3D rather than F3DEX2, effectively doubling some rendering work. Despite this, the level still performed acceptably, suggesting meaningful performance headroom once the correct export path and additional optimizations are applied.
key_stories.challenge: Uncertain N64 performance budget for a large, visually dense level.
key_stories.process: Tested on N64, investigated pipeline/export settings, recognized the incorrect display list format and enumerated pending optimizations (culling, sorting, collision map).
key_stories.outcome: Increased confidence that the level can hit target performance after proper export and planned optimizations.
key_stories.key_quote: I was exporting it as an F3D model and not F3DEX2… and it still ran fine.

key_stories.title: Chasing an 'infinite ocean' under N64 culling limits
key_stories.summary: Kaze spends most of the stream iterating on how to make the ocean feel vast without exposing skybox seams or triggering the N64’s far-distance culling. He experiments with fog distances, horizon gradients, camera-following translation multipliers, and draw-order/layer changes, concluding some NBG-style ideas cannot work when level elements touch the background.
key_stories.challenge: Create a convincing distant ocean and industrial background without claustrophobic fog or visible skybox artifacts, within hardware visibility limits.
key_stories.process: Adjusted fog start/end, tried NBG-like techniques, changed mesh ordering/material sorting, tuned camera-relative movement multipliers (e.g., 0.8–0.95 range), and compared against Biobak’s mock/idea.
key_stories.outcome: Arrives at a “good enough” background approach and plans to add distant metal constructs/cutouts for scale while keeping geometry manageable.
key_stories.key_quote: If anything's too far away from the camera it's gonna just not be visible… it's a hardware limitation.

key_stories.title: Coin placement triggers visual corruption and a suspected load/unload edge case
key_stories.summary: After adding coin formations to make the level feel less empty, Kaze encounters major rendering corruption (floor/material weirdness and missing coin model). He narrows it down to something associated with coin/object setup and suspects an unload/reload requirement for the coin model per area and/or a memory corruption chain, but doesn’t fully diagnose it on-stream.
key_stories.challenge: New content (coin formations) unexpectedly breaks rendering stability/visuals.
key_stories.process: Removes recent changes, observes persistence of corruption, hypothesizes coin model unload per-area and searches for the triggering object/definition; acknowledges lack of a solid theory by the end of the debugging attempt.
key_stories.outcome: Problem is partially mitigated/understood at a symptom level (coin model load behavior), but root cause remains open for later investigation.
key_stories.key_quote: I think the yellow coin model got unloaded… That is actually very concerning.

key_stories.title: Replacing the Bowser switch with a faithful 'upgraded' model
key_stories.summary: Kaze evaluates alternative switch models and rejects a high-poly option (~4000 polys) in favor of a more efficient one (~1336 polys). He then imports Biobak’s improved switch asset, praising it as a better, Mario-64-faithful upgrade.
key_stories.challenge: Improve the switch look while keeping performance and Mario 64 visual language intact.
key_stories.process: Compare poly counts and aesthetic fit; import Biobak’s asset; discuss texture format tradeoffs (RGBA vs CI8/palette cost).
key_stories.outcome: Adopts Biobak’s improved switch and continues level polish with a performance-aware mindset.
key_stories.key_quote: This actually just looks like an upgraded version of the Mario 64 one.

key_stories.title: Early monetization plan: physical boxes, OST ROM, and paying contributors
key_stories.summary: Kaze shares that a merch company offered custom printing, sparking an idea: sell N64-style boxes/manuals as merch and keep distribution of game data separate. He also talks about paying collaborators (including musicians) via royalties/rights if the project generates revenue.
key_stories.challenge: Find ways to monetize a Nintendo-adjacent ROM hack while minimizing legal risk and supporting collaborators.
key_stories.process: Brainstorm product split (box/manual vs ROM), propose an OST-only ROM product, and discuss revenue-sharing expectations with contributors.
key_stories.outcome: No final decision, but a concrete direction emerges for interview follow-up: what’s legal, what’s fair compensation, and how they’d operationalize it.
key_stories.key_quote: I was offering to pay the musicians as well… once everything's done.

open_questions.topic: Bowser protest level goals and identity
open_questions.context: Kaze frames the session as starting work on the “Bowser protest” level, but the stream focuses heavily on ocean/background and minor interactions (switch, coins).
questions: What is the narrative premise of the “Bowser protest” level, and how does it connect to the game’s broader theme/structure?
What is the intended player objective loop in this level (stars, hazards, setpieces), beyond traversal and crane interactions?
Which parts were blocked by missing Zeina animation, and what was the intended character/NPC role?

open_questions.topic: Up64 crash fix and N64 stability improvements
open_questions.context: Kaze says he found the bug that caused only Up64 to crash and that RTYI is now very stable on N64, but doesn’t explain the root cause or fix.
questions: What specifically caused Up64 to crash while RTYI otherwise ran, and how did you isolate it?
Was it an RSP/RDP issue, memory layout issue, undefined behavior, or toolchain difference?
What tests or QA process do you use to claim N64 stability (stress scenes, long-play, memory checks)?

open_questions.topic: Coin model unload / memory corruption incident
open_questions.context: Adding coin formations appeared to cause severe corruption; Kaze suspects coin model unloading per-area and possibly memory corruption, but ends without a solid theory.
questions: What ultimately caused the coin-related corruption—was it an object list overflow, display list overflow, segment pointer issue, or custom code regression?
How does RTYI manage per-area model/resource loading (coins, NPCs) compared to vanilla SM64?
Did this lead to new debugging tools, assertions, or build-time checks to prevent recurrence?

open_questions.context: Kaze iterates through multiple background strategies and concludes some NBG techniques are impossible due to culling radius and skybox interaction.
questions: What final technique did you settle on (camera-follow translation, layered meshes, fog tuning, 2D cutouts), and what tradeoffs did you accept?
How do you decide fog distances artistically vs technically on real hardware?
Are there level design constraints you imposed to prevent players from reaching camera heights that reveal the illusion breaking?

open_questions.topic: Performance optimization roadmap for large levels
open_questions.context: Kaze lists pending optimizations: backface culling, triangle sorting, collision map reduction, render areas, and maybe microcode improvements.
questions: What order do you implement and validate these optimizations in, and how do you measure impact on real N64?
How much performance do you realistically expect from triangle sorting and culling in this specific level?
What is your current polygon/tri budget philosophy per area for RTYI?

open_questions.context: Kaze estimates microcode optimization could yield ~4–5% performance, but doesn’t specify whether that’s via F3DEX3 work or project-specific tweaks.
questions: What microcode are you using in RTYI right now (F3DEX2, F3DEX3 variants), and what changes are on the table?
Is this something you’d collaborate on with Sauraen or others again?
What are the risks (compatibility, emulator variance, tooling) of microcode-level changes for RTYI?

open_questions.topic: Matrix Stack Fix and lighting direction
open_questions.context: Kaze explains the camera-transformed-light problem in SM64 and credits Wiseguy’s Matrix Stack Fix as the solution.
questions: When did you adopt Matrix Stack Fix, and what did it unlock visually for RTYI?
Did it introduce any regressions (custom camera behavior, object transforms, performance)?
How do you balance vertex colors vs dynamic lighting across the game’s art direction?

open_questions.context: Kaze praises the updated NEMU64 and mentions GDB debugging via plugin.
questions: How does NEMU64 fit into your debugging workflow versus other emulators/flashcart testing?
What kinds of bugs (rendering, timing, memory) does it help you solve that other tools don’t?
Do you maintain reproducible debug scenes/ROMs for the team to share?

open_questions.context: Kaze brainstorms selling N64-style boxes/manuals without the ROM and selling an OST-only ROM; he frames this as potentially legal and scalable.
questions: What legal advice (if any) are you getting about selling boxes/manuals tied to a Nintendo property or to RTYI branding?
How would you distribute the actual game if not bundled—patches only, separate download, or something else?

open_questions.context: Kaze talks about paying musicians and a chat contributor jokingly negotiates royalties; it hints at future formalization as revenue grows.
questions: Do you have (or plan) written agreements for music, art, and code contributions?
